snippet.textDisplay: Lol! The Josh Whedon joke.﻿

I'm just going to say that I think this was a fantastic movie just because 
it show Christians how to live that they should stand up for what they 
believe in and not hide away from it and be ashamed of it. And further more 
this movie is aimed at Christians but I'm just saying. If you don't believe 
in God that's fine, I'm not going to change your mind and you won't be able 
to change mine, but please don't go dissing something that a lot of people 
really admire for it's great message. Now I will once again say that this 
is just my opinion and it's not supposed to change anyone's mind because I 
know it probably won't.
Thank you...﻿

You...are...disgusting. Finally, we get a movie that honors God and you 
spit on it. I award you no points for this, I dislike this, I reported 
it...and may God have mercy on your soul.﻿

+menslady125 


IT doesn't represent the atheist's side of the argument which is bullshit.
Stop being a pussy. It's just a shitty movie lol.

+menslady125 That doesn't make a single difference. Falsely reporting a 
video based off of your own religious biases is a blatant abuse of 
YouTube's reporting system. You feel as though no one should be able to 
watch this and that he should have his work taken down simply because you 
don't agree with it. People are allowed to criticize whatever they want in 
whatever way they want. And you have yet to answer for the fact that his 
criticisms of the movie itself (based on no religious preferences 
whatsoever) are solid. The movie is insanely heavy handed in its message, 
it portrays nonchristians as raging, unhappy assholes, and shows Christians 
as all knowing saints who always ask, "what would Jesus do?" When 
questioning whether or not they should do something as small as tying their 
shoes.

+Ryan Wittert

+Mike Todd

+menslady125
Of course you don't. Now tell me, what about this movie makes it so it 
deserves to not be criticized? Is it the generalization of people in

+Koba4329
Well...that I can definitely answer. I was not trolling when I wrote that

+menslady125 You've made me laugh about 4 times tonight. So i think you 
deserve an explanation as to what i mean.

being satirical, or actually having such strong and sincere beliefs.

To simplify. I cant tell if you're trolling or being serious.

+Koba4329
I don't even know what that is.
+menslady125 You are a very Explicit case of Poe's law.

+Mike Todd
I don't know what Ellipsis is, but you are not helping. My point is that 
there is no excuse for bashing movies like this.

+menslady125 This honestly has to be a troll. He stated at the beginning of 
his video that he had no religious bias towards this movie. If "Josh" was 
an atheist and the professor guy was a christian, people would have the 
same response towards this movie because it's unclear on it's point and

I mean this movie points Christians out to be these perfect being and

Also with this comment you are implying that all theistic movies are good. 
There are plenty of Christian/theistic movies on Netflix, so why is this 
any different? 

Nice use of the Ellipsis by the way.

+Larson Davidson
SHUT UP! It IS offensive!
+Joey Lagono 22 That is what I was implying.

matter what anyone says 2e are all equal and that will never change

Don't you dare call me an asshole! YOU'RE an asshole! I can report

There are people like him.

+MC Labs15

If you don't like the movie don't whatch it it clearly seas on the front

you knew was about god ﻿

+ThatClassic70sGirl
*"No, it's an accurate summary of practically everything you wrote in your 
last post. You are turning commonsense morality and even the English 
language on its head and making them both meaningless."*

That is not what I'm doing nor is it what the Bible says absent the most 
loose interpretation possible. Even if the Bible did clearly say it, that 
still wouldn't be an explanation. It would be a declaration. It's just an 
opaque piece of writing that people like you get to quote to anyone they 
disagree with at any given time. It's not an argument. It's an insult at 
best.

*"What the filmmakers are saying is that atheists are not created in a 
vacuum. If their lives could be reviewed and examined in detail, without 
exception there will always be some incident(s) or circumstances 
characterizing their formative childhood-to-young-adult years that 
predisposes them towards not being able to properly relate to God as an 
authoritative, loving father-figure."*

You have no idea what you're talking about. You want to dismiss 
disagreement not by arguing against it reasonably, but by attributing it to 
a traumatic experience. You think that for someone to hold a different view 
to yours, they must be damaged in some way. This is the reason the movie is 
disliked. It tells people that atheists don't believe in your fairy tale 
not out of reason, but out of disdain towards your imaginary friend. This 
kind of patronizing pseudo-psychology is going to piss people off.

How dare you condescend to a group of people like this and whine about the 
predictably, and rightfully negative feedback you get.

*"That's their hypothesis; and because of the self-deceiving nature of the 
unregenerated human heart, you can't prove it wrong."*

Oh, okay. I can play this game too. Christians believe in an imaginary 
father figure only because they failed to connect to their real parents. 
And because of the self-deceiving nature of a damaged human brain, you 
can't prove it wrong. Any Christian can personally disagree with and deny 
it; but they can't negate it.

*"And not all people who claim to know and follow Christ in their lives, 
really do."*

Please Google "No True Scotsman Fallacy".

*"If they have a lackadaisical, dismissive attitude toward the authority of 
Scripture, as many have shown here, then they usually could care less about 
it—and it shows."*

Unless you support slavery and the stoning of unruly children, this is 
equally applicable to you.

*"If you "don't know" whether the filmmakers' heart intentions were good, 
why not give them the benefit of the doubt, and just say you don't know, 
rather than completely trashing their efforts? Isn't that what any fair, 
unbiased, "good-but-not-religious" atheist (according to your own 
worldview) would do?"*

No. The movie is blatantly insulting to atheists for reasons I don't feel 
the need to repeat. They either intended to insult us, or had good 
intentions that were so misguided that it's inexcusable.

*"Maybe the reviewer was trying to be funny; but what he Doesn't have the 
right to do (to borrow your own rationale here) is to impose his own 
worldview onto the movie's creators; and imply that THEY were joking and 
that THEIR message was not intended (by them) to be taken seriously."*

First of all, he isn't "imposing his views" in any way that isn't equally 
applicable to the filmmakers. And secondly, whether or not the message was 
intended to be taken seriously is absolutely irrelevant. It can be joked 
about nevertheless.

*"an angry, disillusioned college professor being hit by a car and mortally 
wounded"*

I thought this was cause for celebration...

*"Something else our friend ralph knows, but conveniently and deliberately 
overlooks (as apparently do you also), is that it's NOT "a man dying 
because of a hit and run" that is being spoken of as "a cause for 
celebration." Rather, it is the fact that despite the plans of the devil 
(and his control of things for many years), the atheist professor's soul 
was saved in the nick of time; and that he was now in the presence of God 
the Father in heaven"*

So someone can live as despicable a life as possible, but if they accept 
Jesus within the last five seconds of their existence, they are rewarded 
with eternal bliss. This is an absolutely awful philosophy.

*"But of course since you (and the reviewer) completely dismiss that 
reality as even a potential possibility, it's easier just to take things 
totally out-of-context"*

It's actually a lot worse in that context.

*"and pretend that the big bad, biased, Bible-thumping fundie-Christians 
were all happy and ecstatic that the evil, hateful, argumentative professor 
got Exactly what was coming to him."*

The evil, hateful, argumentative professor had eternal bliss coming to him? 
Gotcha.

*"Do you honestly think that Mina would've been feeling completely happy 
and joyous, smiling carefree and enjoying herself at the concert, had she 
known at the time that her ex-boyfriend (fiancé/S.O.- whoever) just got 
killed a few minutes prior in an auto accident while (of all things) trying 
to find and talk with/apologize to her for his boorish behavior?"*

So is it cause for celebration or not? Please make up your mind.

*"If so, then you might want to think about the mental gymnastics you are 
willing to engage in order to prop up your godless worldview, including the 
insistence on the "freedom" to run your own life completely apart from the 
acknowledgement of the One who gave you your first breath you ever took, 
and Who will still be there when you take your last."*

I'm not here to listen to a sermon.

*"Atheists do get under my skin at times. But it's because of their 
militancy, the way they insult and taunt Christians"*

And Christians don't do this to atheists?

*"I did not, however, find the professor's death comical, or even a 
"high-point" of the movie. I likewise find no satisfaction in those like 
yourself who are determined to go to a Christless eternity"*

I'm not going to experience an eternity. I'm finite.

*"I hope you'll rethink this and change your mind."*

Why on earth would I? What reason do I have to believe that Christ is 
watching me and will punish me for not obeying him? What reason do I have 
to believe this is true??

+Caradog V "This isn't an explanation. This is a whine."

No, it's an accurate summary of practically everything you wrote in your 
last post. You are turning commonsense morality and even the English 
language on its head and making them both meaningless. 

What the filmmakers are saying is that *atheists are not created in a 
vacuum.* If their lives could be reviewed and examined in detail, without 
exception there will always be some incident(s) or circumstances 
characterizing their formative childhood-to-young-adult years that 
predisposes them towards not being able to properly relate to God as an 
authoritative, loving father-figure. Seldom is it something they'd 
consciously admit to themselves, much less to other, casual acquaintances 
or virtual strangers whom they disagree with; but it's often something that 
just a few close family members or friends are even aware of, and only God 
knows in full detail. *That's* their hypothesis; and because of the 
self-deceiving nature of the unregenerated human heart, you can't prove it 
wrong. Any atheist can personally disagree with and deny it; but they can't 
negate it.

>"Not all Christians have a strict anti-profanity rule..."

And not all people who claim to know and follow Christ in their lives, 
really do. You are aware of this, right? Not all of them are aware of when 
they sin, much less be personally grieved by it, or even resolve to do 
better. Mostly it's because they are either ignorant (as in not knowing—the 
Bible teaches that we have a sinful seared conscience—"conscience" 
literally meaning *with + knowledge* ) or disbelieving of what the Bible 
teaches about these things. If they have a lackadaisical, dismissive 
attitude toward the authority of Scripture, as many have shown here, then 
they usually could care less about it—and it shows. 
But they are sincerely wrong. I try not to even use "minced oaths" like 
"gosh," "darn" "oh God," etc., because of what they stand for and signify. 
I'm not claiming to be perfect by any means; but God is most concerned with 
our attitudes, and whether we accept the truth of what He has clearly told 
us about a thing, or if we ignore, make excuses for, taking pleasure in sin 
and finding it "comical". Personally, although you yourself obviously don't 
believe or accept it (that's not the point here), *for those who do claim 
to follow Jesus Christ,* I think the evidence of the Bible is clearly on 
the side of caution. But judge for yourself what you think it says:

http://www.openbible.info/topics/using_profanity

If you "don't know" whether the filmmakers' heart intentions were good, why 
not give them the benefit of the doubt, and just say you don't know, rather 
than completely trashing their efforts? Isn't that what any fair, unbiased, 
"good-but-not-religious" atheist (according to your own worldview) would do?

Maybe the reviewer was trying to be funny; but what he *Doesn't* have the 
right to do (to borrow your own rationale here) is to impose his own 
worldview onto the movie's creators; and imply that THEY were joking and 
that THEIR message was not intended (by them) to be taken seriously. The 
overall context and presentation of the entire movie disproves that 
assertion. You don't hear any "laugh tracks" on the original footage; plus 
the themes presented in the movie—a college student's education, degree and 
future career/livelihood being threatened; a young woman being diagnosed 
with terminal cancer; an older woman struggling with dementia; and an 
angry, disillusioned college professor being hit by a car and mortally 
wounded—none of these topics are presented as subjects to incite humor; and 
ralphthemoviemaker very well knows it.

Something else our friend ralph knows, but conveniently and deliberately 
overlooks (as apparently do you also), is that it's NOT "a man dying 
because of a hit and run" that is being spoken of as "a cause for 
celebration." Rather, it is the fact that despite the plans of the devil 
(and his control of things for many years), the atheist professor's soul 
was saved in the nick of time; and that he was now in the presence of God 
the Father in heaven—totally restored (healed both physically and 
spiritually), in complete joy and happiness; and reunited with the people 
(including his mother) whom he'd lost to illness as a young boy—*That* is 
"[the] cause for celebration".
But of course since you (and the reviewer) completely dismiss that reality 
as even a potential possibility, it's easier just to take things totally 
out-of-context and pretend that the big bad, biased, Bible-thumping 
fundie-Christians were all happy and ecstatic that the evil, hateful, 
argumentative professor got *Exactly* what was coming to him. The same with 
the students and young adults shown at the Newsboys concert afterwards. Do 
you honestly think that Mina would've been feeling completely happy and 
joyous, smiling carefree and enjoying herself at the concert, had she known 
at the time that her ex-boyfriend (fiancé/S.O.- whoever) just got killed a 
few minutes prior in an auto accident while (of all things) trying to find 
and talk with/apologize to her for his boorish behavior? Do you think she 
(or any mature, conscientious Christian, really—I'm not referring to jaded, 
worldly teenagers here) would have thanked and praised God that he was now 
dead and completely out of her life for good?
If so, then you might want to think about the mental gymnastics you are 
willing to engage in order to prop up your godless worldview, including the 
insistence on the "freedom" to run your own life completely apart from the 
acknowledgement of the One who gave you your first breath you ever took, 
and Who will still be there when you take your last.
Yes, I admit it. Atheists *do* get under my skin at times. But it's because 
of their militancy, the way they insult and taunt Christians, opposing 
themselves and even leading others astray who are more undecided. " And 
even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them 
over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient... 
 Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which commit such things are 
worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do 
them." (Romans 1:28-32). I did not, however, find the professor's death 
comical, or even a "high-point" of the movie. I likewise find no 
satisfaction in those like yourself who are determined to go to a 
Christless eternity despite everything. I know you'll resent me for saying 
so; but I hope you'll rethink this and change your mind.

+ThatClassic70sGirl Then say it's in bad taste. That's fine, there's no 
requirement for you to like the joke. However, what you don't get to do is 
assume that it's not a joke, and that it's meant to be taken seriously. 
Also, all the reviewer did was say a man dying because of a hit and run is 
not a cause for celebration. If you think it is, then there's little more 
to say than: You're insane.

*"" He who is not with Me is against Me, and he who does not gather with Me 
scatters." -Jesus Christ (Luke **11:23**). There is no "middle ground"."*

Jesus Christ is wrong. Sorry, but neutrality doesn't become opposition just 
because he says so.

*"But that is a very serious accusation for any imperfect, sinful (by 
nature) human being to make towards the Son of God."*

See, you're not hearing me. I am not a naturally sinful being, nor is Jesus 
the son of God.

*" It is your choice and the consequences will be your responsibility; but 
as for myself, I choose to believe Him."*

This is a passive aggressive threat. Nothing more. You can't threaten me 
with things I don't believe in.

*"The directors and producers of God's Not Dead did not intend their movie 
to be a caricature or comedy, it is a serious movie with a very serious, 
sincere message."*

Then it fails in absolutely all of its endeavors. Not a single atheist 
worked on or was consulted for the movie, and there are no actual atheist 
characters in the movie. Just someone who hates God. It's a complete and 
utter caricature.

*"The scene in question is where the elderly mother of Dean Cain's 
character has a moment of mental and spiritual clarity, where she answers 
her son's question in several well-articulated sentences just why the fact 
that his career, finances and personal life is going oh-so-well for him at 
that point in time (with no apparent challenges or adversity) can very 
easily be a trap, rather than a confirmation that he is on the right path 
in life. Shortly afterwards she looks at him blankly and asks, "Who did you 
say you were again?" He is emotionally shaken; and it's not a scene easily 
explained away by a crass joking "reviewer""*

It doesn't need to be explained away. It's a movie. It didn't actually 
happen. You are aware of this, right?

*"I'm just pointing out that it wasn't something "Ralph" could so easily 
make fun of; and so he left it out."*

It actually isn't hard at all to make fun of. I've seen numerous reviews in 
which it is made fun of.

*"If you do not see why the flippant, mocking use of profanity (as the 
reviewer repeatedly engages in) is incompatible with Christianity and even 
most conservative religious faiths"*

Not all Christians have a strict anti-profanity rule, and even if they did, 
it omits Christianity as a possibility. Not all religion.

*"You go out of your way to give the reviewer every positive concession, 
regardless of how implausible based on his clearly demonstrated worldview 
and behavior; and not a single credit whatsoever to the intentions and 
heart motivations of the filmmakers."*

Do you know why this is? It's because the review was good, and the film was 
not. I don't even know that the filmmakers' intentions were good. They 
wouldn't have converted anyone with it. All they did was say, "Atheists, 
you hate God." Which all atheists have probably heard hundreds of times 
before.

*"And you want to charge them with bias?"*

Liking one thing whilst not liking another is not bias. Sorry.

*""Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil; Who put darkness for 
light, and light for darkness; Who put bitter for sweet, and sweet for 
bitter!""*

This isn't an explanation. This is a whine.

+Caradog V - So you think it's "comedy" to make fun of elderly and the 
sick, and to mock conservative beliefs because you don't share them? If 
it's a "joke," it's in extremely poor taste, showing no consideration, 
home-training or proper manners/respect at all, at the very least. The 
reviewer advocates for a secular humanistic worldview (against Jesus Christ 
and faith) in many places throughout the movie review; but perhaps the most 
obvious is when he places the value of earthly, temporal life above eternal 
life (near the end).

"Some people are apathetic towards Christianity. Some people are neither in 
its favor or against it. This is a simple fact."

" He who is not with Me is against Me, and he who does not gather with Me 
scatters." -Jesus Christ (Luke 11:23). There is no "middle ground".

You can say (in essence) that Jesus spoke lies, or was fallible, whatever 
(when you say "Jesus saying something does NOT make it true," it is the 
same as accusing Him of lying or being ignorant). But that is a very 
serious accusation for any imperfect, sinful (by nature) human being to 
make towards the Son of God. He said, "if you do not believe that I am He, 
you will die in your sins." (John 8:24); also in John 14:6, "I am the way, 
the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me." It 
is your choice and the consequences will be your responsibility; but as for 
myself, I choose to believe Him. As I would not want anyone to miss out on 
the hope of eternal life, I hope and pray that you will, also.

The directors and producers of *God's Not Dead* did not intend their movie 
to be a caricature or comedy, it is a serious movie with a very serious, 
sincere message.

"How is the scene he edited out more likely to make people support it???"

No need for triple question-marks. The scene in question is where the 
elderly mother of Dean Cain's character has a moment of mental and 
spiritual clarity, where she answers her son's question in several 
well-articulated sentences just why the fact that his career, finances and 
personal life is going oh-so-well for him at that point in time (with no 
apparent challenges or adversity) can very easily be a trap, rather than a 
confirmation that he is on the right path in life. Shortly afterwards she 
looks at him blankly and asks, "Who did you say you were again?" He is 
emotionally shaken; and it's not a scene easily explained away by a crass 
joking "reviewer" determined to drag every idea of Christianity down; but 
never mind—you'll just dismiss this as "propaganda" just like you have 
everything else. I'm just pointing out that it wasn't something "Ralph" 
could so easily make fun of; and so he left it out.

"Again, how does this (cursing) indicate any religion?"

If you do not see why the flippant, mocking use of profanity (as the 
reviewer repeatedly engages in) is incompatible with Christianity and even 
most conservative religious faiths, then either you do not understand the 
faith (do not know the Bible) or your sense of morality has become so 
skewed that you can no longer discern right from wrong; or even what is 
considered acceptable among strangers communicating and interacting in 
polite society. You go out of your way to give the reviewer every positive 
concession, regardless of how implausible based on his clearly demonstrated 
worldview and behavior; and not a single credit whatsoever to the 
intentions and heart motivations of the filmmakers. And you want to charge 
*them* with bias?
The Bible has an explanation for this lack of discernment, which is pretty 
much prevalent among the majority of people in today's world:

"Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil;
Who put darkness for light, and light for darkness;
Who put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!" (Isaiah 5:20).

+deadlyspinner How the fuck is someone supposed to know the movie is bad 
before watching it? I see this argument so many times and it's getting 
annoying by now.

+ThatClassic70sGirl 
*"(like at **3:08**, when he makes fun of Alzheimer's patients; mocking 
those with terminal cancer at **4:28** and the altruistic virtue of 
kindness/edification at **4:53**)"*

How does this indicate religious bias? And how does this have any 
consequence in reality? It's a joke. If you're going to call it "filth" 
you'll be needing to present an argument.

*"("These people are gonna f---ing dislike the video, anyway..." "Oh s---, 
this movie's gonna suck..."; "Who the f--- are you?" and "Are you f---ing 
kidding me??")"*

Again, how does this indicate any religion? And even if it does show he's 
not a Christian, this doesn't tell you what he is, it just tells you what 
he's not. And bear in mind, Jesus saying something does NOT make it true. 
There actually is a middle ground. Some people are apathetic towards 
Christianity. Some people are neither in its favor or against it. This is a 
simple fact.
 The reviewer criticizes the film for its cinematography for the most part. 
Show me one place he debates religion.

*"They can criticize the casting, the dialogue, and other technical aspects 
of the movie"*

... Yeah, since this is a MOVIE review. The point of the video is NOT what 
this video is meant to pick apart. If a movie is not well made, then it's a 
bad movie, regardless of its message. How is the scene he edited out more 
likely to make people support it???

*"Would he honestly admit the mockery and shallow, stereotyped straw-men 
characters it sets up to represent conservative Christianity?"*

I don't know, but until you can demonstrate that he wouldn't, your claim 
will not be treated as true.

*"Or would he be laughing his head off and praising the "comedic wit" the 
"superior writing" and brilliant casting?"*

I don't know. Is it a comedy, and is it a good one. Here's the thing, a 
movie making stereotypes and mockery of a group is okay as comedy. The 
issue with God's Not Dead is that it expects its caricatures to be taken 
seriously.

*"I think we all already know the answer to that question."*

Really...? How ever do we know that??

+Caradog V It was the *type* of voiceovers he added just in the first five 
minutes of the review (like at 3:08, when he makes fun of Alzheimer's 
patients; mocking those with terminal cancer at 4:28 and the altruistic 
virtue of kindness/edification at 4:53) You say, "It's done for comedic 
value." Well, if you consider that "comedy," you're biased. It's filth. 
It's indicative (i.e. a symptom) of what is wrong with 95+% of the world 
today.

He patronizingly says, "I'm not going to tell you whether I'm a Christian, 
or a Muslim, or an atheist, because that's none of your concern." He didn't 
have to make that statement. It's obvious he's not a Christian because of 
the language he flippantly uses ("These people are gonna f---ing dislike 
the video, anyway..." "Oh s---, this movie's gonna suck..."; "Who the f--- 
are you?" and "Are you f---ing kidding me??"). And as Jesus said, we are 
either for or against Him (Matt. 12:30-37). There is no middle "neutral" 
ground like the reviewer (and some others here) prefer to pretend. It's 
quite clear the reviewer is either not familiar with Colossians 3:8; 4:6; 
Psalm 10:4-7; Ephesians 4:29, 5:4; or James 1:26 or chapter 3 at all; or if 
he is, he's quite thoroughly dismissed it as totally irrelevant to his 
life. The trash that comes out of his mouth obviously doesn't bother him 
one iota. He thinks it's funny and cute; and that his viewers should all 
find it comical as well. As such his opinion on the value of a 
*Christian-themed* movie is skewed from the get-go. The fact that some 
professing "Christians" here actually agree with him (and would 
unconditionally give him the time of their day on something relevant to 
their faith—NOT his) is especially telling regarding just how much the 
Christian faith and the average American church has been dumbed-down in our 
post-Christian culture.
 
Ironically, he inserts a graphic still of fingers in ears, eyes shut at 2:32. 
That's about what the atheists and agnostics are doing in response to the 
main message of the movie. They can criticize the casting, the dialogue, 
and other technical aspects of the movie (and in some ways, they have valid 
points, if only they would express them respectfully); but when it comes to 
evaluating the underlying spiritual message, he's completely unqualified to 
do so. He's edited out important scenes (such as the part where the elderly 
woman with Alzheimer's experiences a moment of mental clarity—he includes 
part of the visual, but not the dialogue). Why? Because they don't "fit" 
his agenda, which is namely to make fun of the movie and to discourage 
others from supporting it.

I would be VERY curious to see how this supposedly unbiased reviewer would 
weigh in on a movie like (for just one example) "Saved!" - a profane, 
obscene secular mainstream caricature of Christianity starring Mandy Moore 
- http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332375/ Would he honestly admit the mockery 
and shallow, *stereotyped* straw-men characters it sets up to represent 
conservative Christianity? Or would he be laughing his head off and 
praising the "comedic wit" the "superior writing" and brilliant casting? I 
think we all already know the answer to that question.

+ThatClassic70sGirl You don't need to have a religion to criticize 
something for caricaturing other religions. How is adding a voice over 
disrespectful or indicative of bias? It's done for comedic value.

+deadlyspinner You could say something similar about all the reviewers at 
PluggedIn.com, who review (mostly) mainstream secular movies from a 
Christian worldview. They obviously know from the titles (or trailers) 
going in what they're basically about (and hence if they're likely to be 
found offensive). But they still review them so that Christian believers 
and other conservative families won't waste their money at the theater (or 
DVD store) on worthless junk.

+Caradog V It's more than that. He pretends at the beginning that he has no

+TheDapperSwindler What I'm saying is that they are movies where the 
Christian (if they lack the wisdom to avoid them) has to constantly keep

What about *Straight Outta Compton* (for example) is merely "a-Christian"? 
Yes, the young men in question may have been profiled and treated unfairly 
by law enforcement. But at the same time, they were actually 
law-breakers—not to mention breaking God's laws—like when they were abusing 
and dealing drugs and violently mistreating women, as if the police's 
behavior excused anything they might say or do. As the movie reviewer 
concludes, "So is chanting 'F--- the police!' really the moral equivalent 
of Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech (as Jerry Heller 
insists to this day)? Straight Outta Compton will leave lots of people 
thinking that it is."

If gangsta rappers such as Easy-E and Tupak Shakur really believed in God 
(as evidenced by the former wearing a cross, and the latter rapping about 
prayer), in the movie or in real life, they would have sought a more 
peaceful way to promote their (in some cases genuine) grievances and seek 
social justice. Instead they are on stage cursing up a storm, blaspheming 
God, promoting drug abuse and general rebellion against all authority, just 
for the sake of rebellion. That's not just anti-Christian, it's Satanic and 
demonstrating a lack of self-control. Romans 13:1-5 says, "Let every soul 
be subject to the governing authorities. For there is no authority except 
from God, and the authorities that exist are appointed by God. Therefore 
whoever resists the authority resists the ordinance of God, and those who 
resist will bring judgment on themselves. For rulers are not a terror to 
good works, but to evil. Do you want to be unafraid of the authority? Do 
what is good, and you will have praise from the same. For he is God’s 
minister to you for good. But if you do evil, be afraid; for he does not 
bear the sword in vain; for he is God’s minister, an avenger to execute 
wrath on him who practices evil. Therefore you must be subject, not only 
because of wrath but also for conscience’ sake."

In other words, where the laws are good, not contradictory to God's own 
commandments, and doesn't harm anyone (like wearing seat belts in a moving 
vehicle, or avoiding abuse of pharmaceuticals, for example), *go along with 
them*. It's for our own good, and reflects well as a witness of Him. Where 
the law is evil, we are instructed to stand and resist (Acts 4:18-20 - like 
with Operation Rescue engaging in civil disobedience). Peacefully, 
respectfully, humbly, and above all, non-violently. This is not what NWA/ *Straight 
Outta Compton* is advocating. "Fight back! Seek revenge! Hate and destroy! 
Indulge yourself!" I conclude that a movie like *Straight Outta Compton* 
has a lot more to do with mocking, slandering and misrepresenting God than 
what might be apparent on the surface.

+CognizantPsyche
The Second Law of Thermodynamics is best summarized by saying that 
everything moves toward disorder—or a condition known as entropy. This 
bears some explanation and we will consider several examples.
Remember that evolutionists teach that everything is constantly evolving 
into a higher and more complex order. In other words, they believe things 
continue to get better and better instead of worse and worse.
If water being heated on a stove is at 150 degrees Fahrenheit, and the 
burner is turned off, the temperature will drop instead of rise. It will 
move toward colder rather than hotter. If a ball is placed on a hill, it 
will always roll downhill and not uphill. Energy used to perform any 
particular task changes from usable energy to unusable in the performing of 
that task. It will always go from a higher energy level to a lower energy 
level—where less and less energy is available for use.
When applied to the universe, the second law of thermodynamics indicates 
that the universe is winding down—moving toward disorder or entropy—not 
winding up or moving toward more perfect order and structure. In short, the 
entire universe is winding down!
Even evolutionists admit that the theory of evolution and the second law of 
thermodynamics are completely incompatible with each other. Consider: 
“Regarding the second law of thermodynamics [universally accepted 
scientific law which states that all things left to themselves will tend to 
run down] or the law of entropy, it is observed, ‘It would hardly be 
possible to conceive of two more completely opposite principles than this 
principle of entropy increase and the principle of evolution. Each is 
precisely the converse of the other. As [Aldous] Huxley defined it, 
evolution involves a continual increase of order, of organization, of size, 
of complexity…It seems axiomatic that both cannot possibly be true. But 
there is no question whatever that the second law of thermodynamics is 
true’” (The Twilight of Evolution).
Like a top or a yo-yo, the universe must have been “wound up.” Since the 
universe is constantly winding down, the second law of thermodynamics looms 
before us in the form of a great question: who wound it up? The only 
plausible answer is God!

We have established that Creation demands a Creator. Where does this leave 
evolution?
The theory of evolution is shot full of inconsistencies. Evolutionists have 
seized on many theories, within the overall theory of evolution, in an 
attempt to explain the origins of plants, animals, the heavens, and the 
Earth.
Over and over, these “theorists” try to explain how life evolved from 
inanimate material into more complex life forms until it reached the 
pinnacle—human beings.
Yet, as one geologist wrote, “It must be significant that nearly all the 
evolutionary stories I learned as [a] student…have been debunked” (The 
Nature of the Fossil Record, Proceedings of the Geological Association).
Perhaps the biggest reason that so many theories within the overall theory 
of evolution collapse is because they contain terrible logic requiring 
great leaps in faith to believe. Here is one example of a “debunked” 
theory: “Many evolutionists have tried to argue that humans are 99% similar 
chemically to apes and blood precipitation tests do indicate that the 
chimpanzee is people’s closest relative. Yet regarding this we must observe 
the following: ‘Milk chemistry indicates that the donkey is man’s closest 
relative.’ ‘Cholesterol level tests indicate that the garter snake is man’s 
closest relative.’ ‘Tear enzyme chemistry indicates that the chicken is 
man’s closest relative.’ ‘On the basis of another type of blood chemistry 
test, the butter bean is man’s closest relative’” (The Twilight of 
Evolution).

The First Law of Thermodynamics is stated as follows: matter and energy can 
be neither created nor destroyed. There are no natural processes that can 
alter either matter or energy in this way. This means that there is no new 
matter or energy coming into existence and there is no new matter or energy 
passing out of existence. All who state that the universe came into 
existence from nothing violate the first law of thermodynamics, which was 
established by the very scientific community who now seem willing to ignore 
it. In summary, this law plainly demonstrates that the universe, and all 
matter and energy within it, must have had a divine origin—a specific 
moment in which it was created by someone who was all-powerful.
With the coming of the Atomic Age, beginning with the discovery of radium 
in 1898 by Madame Curie, came the knowledge that all radioactive elements 
continually give off radiation. Consider! Uranium has an atomic weight of 
238.0. As it decomposes, it releases a helium atom three times. Each helium 
atom has a weight of 4. With the new weight of 226.0, uranium becomes 
radium. Radium continues to give off additional atoms until eventually the 
end product becomes the heavy inert element called lead. This takes a 
tremendous amount of time. While the process of uranium turning into radium 
is very long, the radium turns into lead in 1,590 years.
What are we saying? There was a point in time when the uranium could not 
have existed, because it always breaks down in a highly systematic, 
controlled way. It is not stable like lead or other elements. It breaks 
down. This means there was a specific moment in time when all radioactive 
elements came into existence. Remember, all of them—uranium, radium, 
thorium, radon, polonium, francium, protactinium and others—have not 
existed forever. This represents absolute proof that matter came into 
existence or, in other words, matter has not always existed!
This flies directly in the face of evolutionary thought—that everything 
gradually evolved into something else. Here is the problem. You cannot have

+chris vargas - First, my apologies for not responding sooner. It wasn't my 
intention to avoid this discussion. I just get so many replies on various 
videos here on YouTube, plus other forums and online groups—many of which 
take place only minutes following my last posting—that it is hard to keep 
up. Even since my last couple posts, I see where there are two more 
responses that have come in just since I started typing this; and it's been 
virtually impossible for me to keep up, even with some that do not require 
a reply or I otherwise decide to just let an issue go unchallenged.

Ok, well, I think I see what you're saying now. I do agree with you, that 
these types of actions would be considered true abuse, and not motivated by 
the spirit of Christ on behalf of these parents and families. A spiritual 
fast, for example, should only be entered into voluntarily by the 
individual partaking in it, motivated by a heart that is broken and seeking 
more of God in their lives—NOT imposed on someone else as a method of 
punishment. While I do believe that the "rod" can be used in some 
circumstances, as Scripture clearly indicates, a child (regardless of their 
age) should *never* be disciplined out of a parent's own anger or 
frustration; or used as a means of vengeance. The Bible (as you probably 
are already aware) calls Christ's followers to "be swift to hear, slow to 
speak, slow to wrath: For the wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of 
God." (James 1:19-20). If parents are inflicting large bruises, sprains, 
lacerations, broken bones, etc., then this is clearly indicative of a 
deeper problem on their behalf which calls for protective intervention.

However, having acknowledged this, in all honesty and fairness I suspect 
such extreme cases would represent the exception, and not the rule among 
most Christian families who are genuinely and humbly living out their faith 
in other areas of their lives. On the other hand, there are those parents 
who were raised "religious" (as you labeled it) in an authoritarian (not 
loving) home, but who have never actually received the spirit of Christ (or 
whom are backslidden); and are acting according to the preconditioning they 
in turn received as children. My father's oldest son was this way toward 
his stepchildren, sadly—not because of how he was raised (because our 
father—also a truck driver, incidentally— was relatively easygoing and 
respectful toward the things of God, even though he himself was not saved 
at that particular time of his life)—but due in some part to the 
conditioning and things he experienced while in military service. Looking 
back, I would say that he likely paid for his transgressions (some of which 
were very serious, if I understood correctly) at least in an earthly sense, 
as he wound up divorced (with many severed family relationships), faced 
multiple financial and health challenges and died before the age of sixty. 

Keep in mind that not all who profess Christ's name are actually truly born 
of His Spirit. Not to suggest that people are perfect; because of course *none 
of us* (Christian or unbelieving) are. But among those who rightfully claim 
His name, there should be a general spirit of humility being displayed in 
their interactions with others (and in dealing with their own mistakes), 
even (or perhaps, especially) within their own families. In the same book 
and chapter that encourages children to "obey [their] parents in the Lord," 
parents are also instructed not to "provoke [their] children to wrath" 
(Ephesians 6:4).

While I'm not sure what you mean by your friend's inability to " 'be gay' 
in his [parents'] house," I do know that in this age of grace (and with 
Jesus' various teachings emphasizing love and forgiveness), it is not any 
believer's place, much less calling, to physically, violently "beat sin out 
of" someone else. It sounds to me like his father was likely raised in a 
traditional, authoritarian home (where stereotypes of gender roles were 
falsely attributed to the Bible, modeled and taught); and thus received his 
son's admission to SSA as a personal insult/threat to his own manhood. 
This, of course is a gross misconception and should never have happened. It 
is my hope and prayer that your friend would be able to see beyond the 
weaknesses and injustices present in his own familial upbringing, to the 
true spirit of Christ and the Father Who loves him (despite his sin) beyond 
all imagining and human capabilities/failings.

>"thats why I don't like Christian propaganda, it is irresponsible with the 
truth of reality and all the darker aspects of the human psyche, it is by 
definition hypocrisy."

I agree with you that the circumstances you described definitely represent 
humans "missing the mark," if not outright, intentional hypocrisy. But I 
think that the objective of the producers of this film, was to present the 
Christian faith in a more functional (not dysfunctional) way of how things *should 
be*; or at least how Christian virtues like faith, prayer, intercession, 
humility and forgiveness (in the wake of human failure) normally operate in 
response to the difficulties that present themselves in our lives. 

I don't necessarily agree with the implication that the Christians were 
presented as false "straw man" characters in this movie. They were not 
perfect or without personal human failings by any means. Josh's girlfriend, 
for instance, may have professed faith; but yet was portrayed as immature, 
shallow and self-centered in her lack of consideration for Josh's own 
convictions and feelings; not to mention her own understanding and 
application of the Bible to her priorities, values and the way she lived 
out her life. Mina was certainly not a paragon of consistent Christian 
virtue, inasmuch as she'd disobediently gotten herself mixed up in an 
unequally-yoked (2 Cor. 6:14-18) relationship with an unbelieving man. Not 
only that, but it was implied in the film that they were sleeping together 
outside of marriage; which not only spoke strongly of hypocrisy to those 
observing her life from the outside, but had to have had a negative effect 
on her own personal relationship and communion with God. The older woman 
suffering dementia obviously didn't have everything figured out, either; 
since her hotshot yuppie attorney son (played by Dean Cain) was such a 
first-class self-centered materialistic, insensitive boor to practically 
everyone around him... For being such a strong Christian, where did she go 
wrong in raising him? (because it didn't happen in a vacuum). She probably 
reflected often on that very question during his young adult years, as she 
saw him becoming more and more self-centered, manipulative and focused on 
his career and money, to the detriment of more important things. Even the 
church pastor learned a lesson or two regarding the simplicity of faith and 
trust in his heavenly Father, via the visiting minister from another 
continent and culture.

I guess maybe I'm not sure what you mean by "Christian propaganda". What 
specifically did you see as propaganda?

+chris vargas - "I have known many of my friends that have suffered abuse 
from their parents in "Christian" families."

Could you define what you deem "abuse" in this context, please?

For example, there are families with teenage and young adult children who 
self-identify as homosexuals or lesbians. The Christian parents have 
essentially said that if they want to stay in their home, they are welcome; 
but they need to respect and abide by their rules; i.e., no sharing a 
bedroom with their partners. This could go for legal adults as well as 
older teens who have still not reached the age of majority. Or in the case 
of the latter (especially) they impose a curfew, dress codes (in cases of 
extremes), or stipulate that they refrain from use of drugs and alcohol; or 
require that they search for gainful employment. 

These types of things are not "abuse"; but the children will say that 
because they want their beliefs and lifestyle to take precedence over their 
parents' own faith beliefs. How is that fair?

+ThatClassic70sGirl
If you want to argue or debate, I am all for it, but don't write a large 
text like these. Go point by point and let me respond.

I'll answer your question first, I do not think it is wrong to use 
profanity in the case that it is not directed at a person during an 
argument, not even for christian. As it is use as a figure of speech not as 
a direct insult.
Example would be :

"This movie fucking sucks"
"This character is so fucking stupid"

Example of direction insult would be
(during a conversation)
"You are a fucking moron"
"You are so fucking stupid"

Thus, no, I don't think profanity is bad, even for christian if use in the 
correct context.
If you use profanity to insult and attack a person( as a insult), then you 
are wrong, no matter what religion you belong.

+KevvlFan - While I'm not avoiding your first question, I have to ask... Do 
*you* think it's right, acceptable and good for Christians to use 
profanity? Why or why not?

*" No matter what your assumption is, you cannot say that he is not a 
christian..."*

What unfounded "assumption" am I making here? Even discounting his 
flagrant, deliberately antagonizing use of profanity (the evidence present 
for all to hear), I would find it *extremely doubtful* that 
ralphthemoviemaker is Christian (and just "hiding" it for purposes of 
"review objectivity"); because for one thing, he is more concerned about 
how the Muslims and atheists are portrayed (i.e., it is clear that he sees 
all faiths as valid, equal paths to God) than the truth about Jesus Christ 
being proclaimed. Near the end of the review he says, "Once again, I am not 
saying I am for religion or against religion..." Who does he think he's 
kidding? A true Christian would strongly and conscientiously avoid 
referring to their faith (because there's no such thing as a Christian 
having a complete *lack of* faith) as "religion." It's a relationship with 
the living, eternal God of the universe.
 
You just can't be a Christian and be "neutral" about something like that. 
Whether you personally accept it or not (that is not the issue here), from 
the Christian belief perspective, there is such a thing as sin. God defines 
what sin is in the Bible. Not only is all of mankind born into it (original 
sin); but we commit sin (of varying degrees) daily, because we have an 
unredeemed sin nature inherited from Adam and Eve. Only Jesus Christ ever 
lived a perfect life on earth without sin, because He is both God and man. 
Without His voluntary blood sacrifice, we would be destined for an eternal 
death, because God is perfectly holy and cannot allow sin in His presence.

So, given that life is temporary—a few short decades, as juxtaposed with 
all of eternity, we try our best to live in the light of that eternity. 
When we accept Jesus' sacrifice for sin on our behalf, He becomes more 
precious to us than anything (or anyone) else. Jesus validated the books of 
the Bible as containing God's truth, and otherwise spoke highly of them 
during His earthly ministry. So Christians also value them, believe, read 
and study on a regular basis, pray and otherwise strive to become more 
Christlike (and do) what God's Word instructs us.

Do you honestly think that if ralphthemoviemaker *were* Christian, he'd 
fail to see any value in the professor receiving Christ into his life 
before he died—*knowing* that he'd be lost for all eternity without Him? 
Instead he rants about how the ministers had (from his perspective) "pushed 
their beliefs" onto him and supposedly took advantage of the natural fear 
and uncertainty he felt as his life came to an end in order to proselytyze 
and gain another spiritual notch in their belts. You can hear the mocking 
skeptical tone in his voice as he narrates that part of the movie. The fact 
that the reviewer chose to take the most cynical possible view reveals much 
about his own spiritual condition.

_"...which is not relevant at all."

It *is* relevant, because it is *a Christian movie*; and someone who does 
not share that faith will miss (and/or find fault with) the main message. 
Guaranteed, every time. The reviewer's lack of faith (for example) is why 
he sees the physical, earthly life as more important than the eternal, 
spiritual one; even though it is made clear that it is almost certain the 
professor will die before medical help can be summoned. Frankly, I think 
the movie would've been better had they had someone call for an ambulance 
*while* they were praying for him, if only to preempt the obvious 
objections from unbelievers in the viewing audience. It didn't have to be 
either/or. I think a lot of possible plot lines that could have been more 
realistically expanded, with more complete character development (such as 
the professor coming to faith more gradually, or through a lesser crisis) 
had to be cut short due to the length of the movie, which was unfortunate. 
But that doesn't make it "pathetic" or a terrible movie. It's just not as 
good as it could have been.

_"Also, Movie is entertainment, in many different ways, you watch a movie 
to enjoy it, both in the message it represents and the way they represents 
it."

Well, I have to disagree with you here, because as a Christian, how could I 
enjoy something that doesn't reflect truth and is dragging my spirit and 
emotions down? In the Book of Philippians, we are instructed, "whatever 
things are true, whatever things are noble, whatever things are just, 
whatever things are pure, whatever things are lovely, whatever things are 
of good report, if there is any virtue and if there is anything 
praiseworthy—meditate on these things." (4:8). Also we are called to be 
"casting down arguments and every high thing that exalts itself against the 
knowledge of God, bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of 
Christ" (2 Cor. 10:5). That goes for entertainment as well. Sure, it'd be 
great to have both high production values *and* a truthful, 
spiritually-uplifting message consistent with God's worldview; but since 
their budget is limited and we couldn't have both, I know which aspect I 
place the most value on.

*"No matter the message it represents, the execution is so poor that the 
message is lost in the process."*

It wasn't lost to me; and neither would I suspect it was lost to the 
majority of committed, mature Christians who watched it.

*" A rose on a turd might still be a rose, but dame[sic] if people going to 
pick it up and smell it."*

Agreed. Only for the majority of Hollywood movies (unlike GND), the "rose" 
is the multi-million dollar "production values" and the "turd" is the story 
itself. To evaluate a movie so highly on production values while ignoring 
the actual underlying message of the story is analogous to a kid receiving 
a brand new, shiny bicycle for Christmas and ignoring it in favor of the 
wrapping paper and box it came in.

In the defense of this movie, which yes, I liked it due to my Christian 
beliefs, is that it is among the first. Not the first Christian drama film, 
but perhaps one of the first theatrically released Christian drama films 
that premieres in more than like, ten theaters and has more advertisement 
than maybe a few posters or something. Correct me if I'm wrong, but it 
seems that way. 

I mean, how many new upcoming trailers have you seen on the newest upcoming 
groundbreaking drama film on the youtube pre-video ads about the life of a 
Christian, or an agnostic struggling to decide ultimately what he believes 
in? I dunno about you, but so far, God's Not Dead is the only one I've 
seen. What I mean is, Christian films are not as well advertised, and does 
not get as much attention. Yeah, I agree, most of the technicals, the 
editing, the music, the acting (I still liked some of the acting), are not 
that great, but I don't think it's entirely the faults of the makers, 
cause' if you have a type of film that that normally does not get a lot of 
media coverage in the theatrical mainstream, then you're film will not have 
as big a budget, and you'll have a harder time getting better actors, 
editors, directors, writers, the works. This is not an argument on the 
points, viewpoints, or story of the movie, just that, maybe the technicals 
of this film could be excusable.

I mean no offense towards Ralph or anyone else, I liked this video, 
actually. I'm not calling anyone stupid for not liking the film just 
because I enjoyed it, or trying to start a religious debate, Ralph kept his 
argument to a mostly non-religious viewpoint, so I will too.﻿

We know it's about the lesson it teaches. The problem is that the lesson is 
riddled with one-sided propaganda.

You make a basic general error. You seem to believe the movie was intended 
to create a philosophical round table for Believers and atheists and 
everything in between to sit down together and try to come to some sort of 
meeting of the minds. It isn't. It never was.

The movie is a statement of faith and belief for Christians who want to see 
something that defends them and what they commit their lives to every day. 
You argue that a better film like this would cause atheists to reconsider 
their lack of faith. No, it wouldn't. Atheists---at least the vast majority 
of those individuals who claim to be atheists---are far more committed to 
their total rejection of the possibility of God than most Christians are to 
their faith. I have never met an atheist (and I have met a good number of 
them) who wasn't far more close-minded than the average Christian.

You say this is propaganda. To some extent you are undoubtedly correct. But 
this was never intended to be Star Wars or Gone With The Wind or E.T. or 
True Grit. This is a story that speaks directly to those Believers who 
frequently feel themselves being pushed back into the shadows by an 
ever-increasing crowd of non-believers who not only don't believe, but are 
increasingly hostile toward those that do. If you didn't like this film at 
all, that is absolutely your prerogative. But if you dislike it because it 
feels unlike what you think a movie should, then you have missed the point 
of why this film speaks so powerfully and so intimately to so many people. 
There is a two minute scene in the latter part of the film that shows Dean 
Cain sitting with his mother who suffers from dementia. He says out loud 
what many, many people---maybe even you---think every day about those of us 
who believe. It captures the heart of the film. I'm sorry its message was 
lost on you. You seem to be an honest man. I think you mean well. But if 
you attempt to understand the heart of "God's Not Dead" by seeing it only 
as a movie, then you will forever remain in the dark.﻿

The reason why there is no room for the "miraculous" is because it's 
meaningless when you look at the big picture. Ever done the experiment 
where you take a 10x10 grid, get 100 unique characters, take the first 
unique character in the top left and advance to the right, repeatedly down 
the 10 rows and calculate the possibility of you doing that? If you reverse 
engineer anything the possibility of the existence of the present relation

you, this answer is the truth, but I may not word it well enough. We ignore

creationism vs. evolution (although it applies equally about any issue that 
secular humanism and Christianity disagrees on), the question is not 
whether one is biased. We *all* are. The question is *which* bias is the 
*best* bias to be biased *with*.
We all have some presuppositions, some source of authority that we accept 
as a given "starting point" in our search for information; but ultimately 
they boil down to the meaning and truth in life. The secular scientist's 
bias is that there is no room for the supernatural or miraculous; and so no 
matter what it is, it's always got to have another explanation, even if 
their experiment or observation is not repeatable and observable (in real 
time) as according to the scientific method of proof. For example, 
scientific dating methods (carbon-14 and radioactive isotopes) essentially 
amount to a tautology; because the assumption that *x* amount of residual 
molecules = *y* million years on the time scale can never be proven by any 
other known objective measuring scale or device, or perceived through the 
five senses. In reality, all dating methods, including those that point to 
a young Earth, rely on many assumptions, because in the end they are closed 
systems.

wow, alright. thanks for sharing anyway. Well, I'm not gonna to force you 
or anything, I just wanna stay cool with people. Plus it would be 
pointless. But i will encourage you and i'd like to tell about my story. 
sorry if my response is long-ish... Yeah, it's pretty hard to believe that 
there is a god. In a world full of lies and untrusted people, you'd really 
want people to give physical evidences to prove the existence of a god. 
Were you Christian or Catholic? Well I grew up as a catholic but away from 
church. my family wasn't really close to God. I've NEVER been to a church 
with my ENTIRE family. i guess you can say that we were like atheists. we 
didn't really cared about God. We'd just do the sign of the cross and junk 
when people say so. ... My family was full of hatred. Favoritism, lies, 
cheats, an uncle who everyone thinks stole from my mother, and a little 
girl whose parents are married to different people. It's sick and 
irritating you know? being related to very sinful people, you'd have a hard 
time trying to find a way to love them (they're humorous, i'll give them 
that.) i even thought about suicide a few times. .. then one day, my mom 
decided i join a catholic church to sing with the chorale. It was more of 
improving my voice actually, not really to serve God. during church, i 
thought most of the things priests' said were nonsense and that some of the 
things they taught shouldn't have been taken literally, and vice versa. i 
also humiliated myself by forgetting what to say in the middle of a Hail 
Mary in the rosary. I didn't even like doing the rosary. but i did talk to 
God more. i finally became happy because of Him. He made me smile for real, 
for the first time in a while. I considered little happy things as 
miracles. But every once in a while i'd forget about Him, so obviously, 
being catholic wasn't enough. .. soon i realized my parents were fighting. 
they talked to each other less but whenever they did talk, it was obvious 
that they were arguing. As the eldest child in our little family, I knew 
what their movements meant. One day i heard myself tell mother "it's ok 
mum, just pray. God will help us" or something like that. She actually took 
the advice and did pray. then she looked for psychiatrists or therapists or 
whatever, i dunno. then someone told her about Christianity, she decided to 
try it out and she liked it. Soon we were attending christian churches and 
our lives have improved. except for my dad. he's more of a magik & sorcery 
guy. he thinks that we are all our own god & we have the potential to be 
God and there are times when my parents still won't get along. he's the 
only one i'm waiting for in our church, but i believe everything is in 
progress. especially my father's heart. God is working on my father's 
heart... these days, my mom attends a Discipleship group every Thursday in 
the city of Ortigas, which is about 2 hours away from where we live. A 
Discipleship group or d-group is a group of people lead by a mentor or 
discipler, like Jesus and His 12 Disciples. Teaching about God and the 
Bible. It's an exhausting and sometimes expensive trip, but it's fun and 
worth it, haha. you learn a lot of things about God and His unconditional 
Love for us. turns out a lot of Filipino celebrities are Christians and 
some are considering to join my mom's Dgroup (really excited about that 
xD). I met a lot of people who are related/friends with famous people. one 
woman in this group has a (ex)husband who was famous in the Philippines for 
a while... for lies and rape. i think he just got out of prison :P we're 
praying for him anyway. .. my mother and i like to think that God is 
providing for us. one time, mom was trying to decide if we should take a 
train or a bus to go there. she felt that we should take the bus so we did. 
when we arrived Ortigas, my mom's Dgroupmates said that the train we ALMOST 
used was hit by another train. And the train that hit it won't stop running 
:O It was all on the news. just about everyone there was injured. that 
night I realized that God was protecting us. .. A few weeks later, after 
talking about money problems, mom and i accidentally rode the wrong bus. 
THAT bus took us to Ortigas in a fast, safer, and less expensive way. mom 
was really amazed xD God really was providing for us. we also attend a BSF 
(bible study fellowship) every Monday. it's cool actually, you learn new 
stuff and actually understand the super complicated and mysterious (for me) 
Bible. BSF is also the place where mom met someone who found a job for her. 
i don't think this was all just a coincidence. and like i said, everything 
is still in progress. .. I can tell you a lot more, but Youtube is not a 
good place to talk about these haha. i hope this helped :/ I admit it, 
there are times when I think “what if God doesn't exist? And if He doesn't 
exist, what happens if I continue spending my life, running after something 
that never existed?” it's just doubting you know. Some things we really 
just have to be faithful about. It can be hard, I know, but at least we 
have something to believe in, and it keeps us thinking that we were put on 
this earth for a reason. That we are actually loved.

(i'm sorry, this is so long xD)

+Lara Pascual *facepalm*
I don't understand why believers think something negative has to happen to 
us to make us lose our faith. Whatever, I might as well start from the 
beginning.
I was practically raised in a church, like many in America. The only 
difference was I never liked going, I didn't want to go, but I didn't have 
a choice. Hell, many of my friends from then and now have said they never 
liked going to church and that they wouldn't if they had the choice. It 
wasn't until recently that I finally admitted to myself that I never really 
believed in any of the things I was taught there. It should have been 
obvious to me, because I always asked questions and I always wanted a 
straight forward factual answer. I knew that people didn't just rise from 
the dead, I knew that there wasn't enough water on earth for it to flood 
higher than Mt. Everest, and I knew the earth wasn't flat and that the 
universe was just a glass dome with dots on it a few hundred feet off the 
ground. The answers I would get were never satisfactory, usually "it's all 
in the bible", but more often I was told not to question it or that I just 
had to "take it all on faith", a concept I was never really contempt with. 
I actually would read the bible, read more than just the cherry picked 
quotes they hammered into our heads, and usually found some very 
disconcerting context being left out. The only reason I kept going in my 
teens after my dad left (the one who forced me to go) was because I 
actually had friends there, which was more than I could say about any other 
facet of my life at the time. It wasn't until I was seven when I decided to 
be honest with myself and admit I didn't believe in anything they told me, 
and it wasn't until I was 14 when I started admitting it to others. I'm 
still friends with some of the people I met in church, but I soon stopped 
going because I found time to be with them outside. I never really called 
myself an atheist, despite being one, until I started researching 
christianity and most other major religions in depth late in my freshmen 
year of high school. I found all these faiths unbelievable, and after 
finding out about how many religiously backed atrocities there were 
throughout the centuries, I said, "There's no way I'm ever going back to 
this delusional nonsense". I would not at all be as outspoken about my 
atheism if I hadn't done my research and found out about all the violence 
and repression. People always tell me that my seven octave vocal range is a 
"gift from god", and to be honest, I'm highly offended by it, because I 
know full well that it was my work with my voice that got me this range, 
not some magical sky wizard. If I had no interest in singing or (voice) 
acting, I would have little to no range at all. Granted, I'd still have an 
awesome, rumble-y low voice, but it wouldn't be the same as being able to 
sing almost any song or impersonate any character voice. So yeah, I'm 
obviously going to be ridiculously offended when people attribute my hard 
work and determination to an ethereal omnipotent sky daddy, but that's 
about as far as experiences go when it comes to pushing me away from 
religion. I've never really been a target of ridicule aside from some 
uncomfortable dinner conversations with family members, and the only other 
thing really upsetting about my character aside from be being an outspoken 
and brutally honest prick at times is the fact that I'm pansexual, which 
has never really been an issue given that I prefer women, leading most to 
assume I'm straight. Hell, I only ever though I was simply bisexual until 
about a year ago, because I knew from a young age that I was attracted to 
both sexes, but found out I wasn't just bi after my friend sent me a link 
to some yuri hentai site containing shemale sex as a joke for my birthday. 
I discovered that I like girls with penises. I know this is a bit 
unnecessarily detailed and personal, but when I ventured through this site 
and even some live action pornography, and after an unfortunate viewing of 
tentacle fetish porn (disturbed and intrigued me in a very unnerving way), 
I realized I was actually pansexual. I'm willing to admit it and I don't 
care who knows.
Back on topic, I think I've covered just about everything. Never had faith, 
never had a reason to believe in a deity, and I'm completely comfortable 
saying that god does not exist until someone can provide me with evidence 
saying otherwise. That's pretty much it. None of my personal experiences 
outside of anything related to religion/theism were linked in any way, 
though I didn't exactly have the greatest childhood, I still never 
attributed anything going on in my personal life to god. There were select 
moments when I may have thought things like, "Why would a god let this 
happen (to me)?", but never really made a habit out of it or took it to 
heart. God and my personal life have pretty much been completely separate 
from each other, not really any correlation between the two.
Okay, I'm done now.

I think you hit upon the major problem with this film: no matter how badly 
it tries to convince you that it is truly opening up a fair discussion 
about atheism vs theism, the execution of it blatantly shows how it tries 
to get you on its side. The whole structure and presentation of the film 
screams, "Look at how atheists are all pretentious, cold, arrogant pieces 
of shit who only don't believe in God because they're angry at him! Don't 
you see how Christians have been right all along?" If you're going to make 
a movie to attack atheists, at least have the decency to be honest and 
forward about your intentions and at least do us the courtesy of not using 
literally every atheist stereotype imaginable. For that matter, stop using 
religious stereotypes too! This movie is positively harmful because it 
undermines the most important element in argument and debate: being able to 
think for yourself and having the right to disagree. The movie may even 
really think that it is letting you decide for yourself, but in an ironic 
twist, just like the evil teacher who forces his opinion down his students' 
throats, the movie itself shoves its opinion down our throats. Fuck this 
movie and the truly arrogant, stupid, unsubtle, ridiculous people who made 
it. ﻿

(English is not my native language, so, I am sorry if I have orthographic 
errors). The movie has many problems and a lot of them have been 
 previously remarked by this video. One of them is the way it portrays 
atheists, of course, but as a philosophy student I am more concerned with 
the arguments used by the student and the professor. They are all 
caricatures of their real counterparts. Many brilliant minds have put 
forward great theological arguments throughout history, and they intended 
to demonstrate the existence of God one way or another (some of the most 
famous people who proposed them are figures like Saint Anselm, Saint Thomas 
Aquinas, Avicena, Al Farabi etc.) The arguments can be discussed rationally 
and they are still pretty important today. Even logical positivism has 
abandoned it's early intention to destroy metaphysical discourse and is now 
playing with theological ideas. Atheists have their own arguments, of 
course, and it's always stimulating to discuss ideas... But this movie is 
just dumb. If you want to defend theism read someone like Frederick 
Copleston or watch an intelligent movie about the subject, but this 
specific film constitutes a terrible ground to defend your position. The 
student and the professor use too many logical fallacies, and that fact 
makes it impossible to take any of the things they say seriously.   ﻿

+FeRnando Ramirez Even if the Gospels were not written until 30 years after 
Christ’s death, that would still place the writing of them prior to the 
destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70. This presents no major problem with 
their authority or accuracy. Passing on oral traditions and teachings was 
commonplace in the Jewish culture of that day, and memorization was highly 
cultivated and practiced. Also, the fact that even at that time there would 
have been a considerable number of eyewitnesses around to dispute and 
discredit any false claims, and the fact that none of the “hard sayings” of 
Jesus were taken from the Gospel accounts, further supports their accuracy. 
Had the Gospels been edited before being written down, as some liberal 
scholars contend, then it was a very poor job. The writers left far too 
many “hard sayings,” and culturally unacceptable and politically incorrect 
accounts that would need explaining. An example of this is that the first 
witnesses of the resurrection were women, who were not considered reliable 
witnesses in the culture of that day.So, whether it was few years or many 
after Jesus’ death that the Gospels were written, we can have total 
confidence and faith in their completeness and accuracy, knowing that they 
were written by “men moved by the Holy Spirit” (2 Peter 1:21), who 
accurately recorded the very words of God.
The fact is that the Bible has not been rewritten. Take the New Testament, 
for example. The disciples of Jesus wrote the New Testament in Greek, and 
though we do not have the original documents, we do have around 6,000 
copies of the Greek manuscripts that were made very close to the time of 
the originals. These various manuscripts, or copies, agree with each other 
to almost 100 percent accuracy. Statistically, the New Testament is 99.5% 
textually pure. That means that there is only 1/2 of one percent of all the 
copies that do not agree with each other perfectly. But, if you take that 
1/2 of one percent and examine it, you find that the majority of the 
"problems" are nothing more than spelling errors and very minor word 
alterations. For example, instead of saying "Jesus," a variation might be 
"Jesus Christ." So the actual amount of textual variation of any concern is 
extremely low. Therefore, we can say that we have a remarkably accurate 
compilation of the original documents.

So when the Bible has been translated, it is not translated from a 
translation of a translation of a translation. It is translated from the 
original languages into our language. It is a one-step process and not a 
series of steps that can lead to corruption. It is one translation step 
from the original to the English or to other languages. So the Bible has 
been translated into Spanish or German or Chinese from the same Greek and 
Hebrew manuscripts. This is how it is done for each and every language into 
which we translate the Bible. We do not translate from the original 
languages to the English, to the Spanish, and then to the German. It is 
from the original languages to the English or into the Spanish or into the 
German. Therefore, the translations are very accurate and trustworthy.

back of my head, I have a voice telling me: "Don't get your hopes up".

common ones include: God/Heaven obviously, Reincarnation, The possibility 
that every living being is actually the same just re-birthed so essentially

infinite can exist then why isn't the universe, So I think about the fact 
that we could be in an never circle, (Universe explodes, reaches a point, 
implodes/explodes again etc, recreating the exact same universe forever in 
a never ending cycle). The are just so many possibilities and I never stay 
on one to long, because I can never know for certain. Hence why I'm 
agnostic. I think of a purgatory, I think that we could be a computer
