+Frieza1500 "I've got a better analogy for you. If your kids disobeyed, 
would you set them on fire?"

Maybe the real underlying question (implied in your statement) is, "Am I 
God's *child*?" 

To illustrate with an analogy, if your preschool-aged child is outside 
throwing rocks (despite your as a parent having warned him several times 
not to) and breaks a neighbor's window, do you set him on fire, as 
punishment? Of course not. You'd likely scold him (or her), maybe give him 
some "time out" in a corner for a while. But your first reaction is going 
to be making sure they didn't accidentally cut themselves on the flying 
glass. If they're significantly injured, you take them to the doctor/clinic 
and have them treated, like any loving parent would do for a child (even 
one who is disobedient). 

But who pays for the replacement for the broken window; and any medical 
bills? *You* do. That's sort of like what happened when God paid the price 
of our ultimate disobedience through the sacrifice of His Son, Jesus 
Christ. He wasn't the One responsible for the wrongs we committed. But as a 
loving Father, He does not simply leave us to deal with the consequences.
Of course there are temporal penalties to pay for sin and disobedience, 
even for children, that may vary given their age and maturity level. 
Suppose for a moment the rock-thrower in our hypothetical scenario is a 
teenager. They might be grounded for a few days, a week, or even a month 
(if they are a repeat offender). Maybe the parent in this case only pays 
for half the cost of the window; and the teen has to make up the other half 
through earnings from their part-time weekend job.
Same offense, right? Yet the penalty is different for a 15-yr-old than it 
would be for a five-year-old. Why? They're older. Their thinking skills 
have had time to mature. They should've known better. Likewise, God often 
disciplines those whom He loves differently, depending on the length of 
time they've been following Him, whether our sin in a particular area is 
becoming habitual, etc. In each case, however, the discipline is motivated 
by His love and to try and keep us from greater harm down the road.
Let's consider a similar scenario where the rock-thrower is a derelict 
adult stranger who is trying to gain access to a home in order to rob it. 
He is caught, arrested, jailed and taken to court. During this process, it 
is discovered that he has a rap sheet for previous offenses. The judge 
pronounces sentence; so he maybe does jail time in addition to paying costs 
of court, restitution (for the broken window), etc.

I realize the analogy is far from perfect. But the point is, the parents 
(God) in this case have no vested interest in advocating for the 
individual. He's of no relationship to them. He is given the full penalty 
the Law (i.e. the O.T. law of "sin and death") allows.

But getting back to your original question (the differentiating factor of 
sonship or "daughter-ship"), you may be familiar with the saying that "God 
has no grandchildren". He only recognizes one method of entering into His 
"family" upon the age of accountability; and that is by adoption. (Romans 
8:14-16; Gal. 4:4-6; Eph. 1:4-6). We aren't automatically "born" believing. 
That's why there are dedication ceremonies in many Protestant churches for 
the parents and their infants/young children, where they promise to "train 
up [their] child[ren] in the way that they should go." (Proverbs 22:6).
A more concise way of illustrating your original question might be more 
relevantly phrased as would we discard a plate or a cup that was 
irreparably broken and no longer able to serve in its original intended 
function. Because we are the creation of God, not the *child* of God (i.e., 
in relationship to Him), until we have willingly and voluntarily accepted 
Him as our Father. It might be some of the most expensive, rare china; but 
if it's in pieces, what's the point of keeping it? 
Of course if one believes in evolution then they do not comprehend 
"creation" in its original sense and framework, with God being preeminent 
and with the right to adopt His own rules for governing His creation and so 
on.

 It doesn't say Mary's father.

from Adam to Jesus, but if everyone came from Adam that's kind of a

Joseph.  And if it's important at all, it would be clear.
